BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Less snow than expected has fallen since yesterday.
The sometimes moderate wind has transported some snow. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls wind slabs formed.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even large ones in isolated cases.
As the moisture increases moist and wet avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m. The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
Above approximately 2200 m a lot of snow is lying.
Further warming: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In some regions increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
Wet and gliding snow at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The southerly wind has transported some snow.
In particular on wind-loaded slopes the avalanches can be triggered in the new snow and wind slab layers. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
As the moisture increases wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind has transported the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
Further warming: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of wet loose snow avalanches being released will increase in all aspects.
The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular on sunny slopes wet loose snow avalanches are possible. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs formed. They must be evaluated with care and prudence. Wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area continuous warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Less snow than expected has fallen since Saturday.
The strong wind has transported the new snow. Adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions wind slabs formed.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.
As the moisture increases moist and wet avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular at low and intermediate altitudes, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2100 m. The southerly wind has transported the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In some regions increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Less snow than expected has fallen since Saturday.
The strong wind has transported the new snow. Adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions wind slabs formed.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.
As the moisture increases moist and wet avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular at low and intermediate altitudes, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2100 m. The southerly wind has transported the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In some regions increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A clear night will be followed by favourable conditions over a wide area. Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Especially on rocky sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition individual small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants on very steep shady slopes. Shady slopes are unfavourable, in particular above approximately 2400 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
In addition the fresh wind slabs in high Alpine regions are prone to triggering in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes.
The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 3000 m.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack especially on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the vicinity of peaks. This applies in particular at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A clear night will be followed by favourable conditions over a wide area. Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Especially on rocky sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition individual small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants on very steep shady slopes. Shady slopes are unfavourable, in particular above approximately 2400 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
In addition the fresh wind slabs in high Alpine regions are prone to triggering in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes.
The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 3000 m.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack especially on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the vicinity of peaks. This applies in particular at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Increase in danger of wet avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Early and late morning:
Fresh wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering on very steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Avalanches can additionally in very isolated cases be released in the old snowpack. These avalanche prone locations are to be found on extremely steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m.
Dry avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

During the day:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually especially on extremely steep sunny slopes. Especially on extremely steep sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible. This also applies in isolated cases on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

In addition further gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a strong wind from southerly directions, wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. The weather effects will bring about a rapid stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning are favourable over a wide area. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Increase in danger of wet avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Early and late morning:
Fresh wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering on very steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Avalanches can additionally in very isolated cases be released in the old snowpack. These avalanche prone locations are to be found on extremely steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m.
Dry avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

During the day:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually especially on extremely steep sunny slopes. Especially on extremely steep sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible. This also applies in isolated cases on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

In addition further gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a strong wind from southerly directions, wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. The weather effects will bring about a rapid stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning are favourable over a wide area. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise from early morning to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. The meteorological conditions will facilitate a weakening of the snowpack in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in terrain.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From the early morning as a consequence of solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of moist avalanches. Fresh and older wind slabs in the high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular on very steep sunny slopes. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions will foster a weakening of the near-surface layers from the early morning. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust will form on the surface during the next few days. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes deep wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A clear night will be followed by favourable conditions over a wide area, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Early and late morning:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases. These avalanche prone locations are to be found on extremely steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. Mostly avalanches are small. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

During the day:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually especially on extremely steep sunny slopes. Especially on extremely steep sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible. This also applies in isolated cases on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

In addition further gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a strong wind from southerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning are favourable over a wide area. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A clear night will be followed by favourable conditions over a wide area, but the danger of wet avalanches will increase later.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Early and late morning:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases. These avalanche prone locations are to be found on extremely steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. Mostly avalanches are small. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

During the day:

The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a strong wind from southerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning are favourable over a wide area. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the early morning.
Especially on rocky east, south and west facing slopes mostly small wet avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition very occasional mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the early morning.
Especially on rocky east, south and west facing slopes mostly small wet avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition very occasional mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day. Especially on rocky slopes mostly small wet avalanches are to be expected.
In addition very occasional mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften quickly. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day. Especially on rocky slopes mostly small wet avalanches are to be expected.
In addition very occasional mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften quickly. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.
